training_organizations.name: New Mexico CYFD – Protective Services Training
training_organizations.description: The New Mexico Children, Youth & Families Department provides an internal training academy for its Protective Services Division staff. New investigators and placement workers learn New Mexico’s practice model, forensic interviewing techniques, and the requirements of the Kevin S. settlement (which mandates reforms in NM’s child welfare). Ongoing training addresses areas like ICWA compliance and engaging with the state’s diverse communities.

training_organizations.name: Binti
training_organizations.description: A private software company providing a foster care licensing and placement platform. New Mexico contracted with Binti in 2020 to pilot an online system for foster and adoptive family approvals:contentReference[oaicite:33]{index=33}. Binti’s software allows potential foster parents to apply online and streamlines CYFD’s licensing and matching process, helping the state increase the speed and efficiency of placing children with families:contentReference[oaicite:34]{index=34}.

training_organizations.name: New Mexico Kids Matter (CASA)
training_organizations.description: An organization that oversees CASA volunteers (Court Appointed Special Advocates) in parts of New Mexico (including the Albuquerque area). These volunteers are trained to advocate in court for children’s best interests. By investigating the child’s situation and speaking up in legal proceedings, CASA volunteers help ensure that judges in New Mexico have a full picture of each child’s needs beyond what the state agency presents.

policies.TribalFoster: Yes, Tribes within state provide foster care
policies.Def_OtherSpecify: Child placed in care or adoption in violation of the law
policies.FatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.Def_Subtype_Abuse: Abuse includes physical abuse, emotional abuse, psychological abuse, sexual abuse and exploitation, injurious environment, punishment; Physical abuse includes malnutrition, failure to thrive, shaken baby syndrome
policies.Def_Subtype_Neglect: Neglect includes abandonment, inadequate subsistence, medical neglect, educational neglect, failure to protect, inability to meet parent responsibilities (when parent/guardian/custodian unable to do responsibilities due to incarceration, hospitalization, physical/mental disorder or incapacity), when child placed in care/adoption in violation of the law
policies.TribalFoster_Specify: All tribes and pueblos in New Mexico: Navajo Nation; Fort Sill Apache Tribe; Jicarilla Apache Nation; Mescalero Apache Tribe; Acoma Pueblo; Cochiti Pueblo; Isleta Pueblo; Jemez Pueblo; Laguna Pueblo; Nambe Pueblo; Ohkay Owingeh Pueblo; Picuris Pueblo; Pojoaque Pueblo; Sandia Pueblo; San Felipe Pueblo; San Ildefonso Pueblo; Santa Ana Pueblo; Santa Clara Pueblo; Santo Domingo Pueblo; Taos Pueblo; Tesuque Pueblo; Zia Pueblo; Zuni Pueblo
policies.TribalReport_Specify: All tribes and pueblos in New Mexico: Navajo Nation; Fort Sill Apache Tribe; Jicarilla Apache Nation; Mescalero Apache Tribe; Acoma Pueblo; Cochiti Pueblo; Isleta Pueblo; Jemez Pueblo; Laguna Pueblo; Nambe Pueblo; Ohkay Owingeh Pueblo; Picuris Pueblo; Pojoaque Pueblo; Sandia Pueblo; San Felipe Pueblo; San Ildefonso Pueblo; Santa Ana Pueblo; Santa Clara Pueblo; Santo Domingo Pueblo; Taos Pueblo; Tesuque Pueblo; Zia Pueblo; Zuni Pueblo
policies.TribalScreen_Specify: All tribes and pueblos in New Mexico: Navajo Nation; Fort Sill Apache Tribe; Jicarilla Apache Nation; Mescalero Apache Tribe; Acoma Pueblo; Cochiti Pueblo; Isleta Pueblo; Jemez Pueblo; Laguna Pueblo; Nambe Pueblo; Ohkay Owingeh Pueblo; Picuris Pueblo; Pojoaque Pueblo; Sandia Pueblo; San Felipe Pueblo; San Ildefonso Pueblo; Santa Ana Pueblo; Santa Clara Pueblo; Santo Domingo Pueblo; Taos Pueblo; Tesuque Pueblo; Zia Pueblo; Zuni Pueblo
policies.InHome_Unsubstantiated: Yes--implemented in specific counties or regions
policies.InvestQual_OtherSpecify: High school diploma; Valid driver's license
policies.ScreenInfo_OtherSpecify: Collect sufficient information to make a screening decision including (1) information received from the reporting source, (2) information from collateral contacts as available, and (3) results of their review of their central registry system for any previous referrals for child abuse and neglect
policies.AntiDiscrim_OtherSpecify: Intersex traits; Citizenship or immigration status; Language; Medical condition, including HIV/AIDS; Status as a survivor of domestic violence, sexual assault, or stalking; Any other non-merit factor
policies.DefAge_VaryByTypeSpecify: The abandonment definition specifies different time periods to be considered abandonment based on whether child is under or over 6 years old
policies.DefPerp_VaryByTypeSpecify: Any person can be a perpetrator for human trafficking
policies.CaseManagerQual_OtherSpecify: A current license or eligibility for licensure for a Doctoral Level Psychologist, Psychologist Associate, LISW, LMSW, LPC, LPCC, LMHC or LMFT
policies.InvestQual_ExperienceSpecify: 4 years of experience and a high school diploma or 2 years of experience and an associate's degree can be substituted for a bachelor's degree
policies.FatalitiesDefine_OtherSpecify: Definition of physical abuse include conditions for child death as the following: (1) there is not a justifiable explanation for the death; (2) the explanation given for death is at variance with the nature of the death; (3) circumstances indicate that the death may not be the product of an accidental occurrence
policies.CaseManagerQual_ExperienceSpec: 2 years of experience including working with communities, working on health or social service related matters, social work/case management experience, behavioral health and/or health care
policies.ScreenerQual_ExperienceSpecify: 4 years of experience and a high school diploma or 2 years of experience and an associate's degree can be substituted for a bachelor's degree
policies.AltResp_EligibilityMaltreatment: Only certain types of maltreatment are eligible
policies.ExtFosterCare_Reentry_OtherSpec: A young adult who has previously participated in the extended foster care program may re-enter the program at any time before their 21st birthday if they meet eligibility criteria
policies.AltResp_Eligibility_OtherSpecify: Cases without serious threat of imminent harm to a child, no immediate safety concerns, does not require law enforcement involvement, and does not require specialized assessment or a traditional investigative approach
policies.AltResp_ServiceReferralOtherSpec: Based on the results of the family assessment
